Ek044yoA6OfNzto4mBCktg.text: I came here with a few friends for a nice Friday night dinner after the holidays. It was the hottest new restaurants of 2014 according to Londonist, so what better way to kick off the new year? The restaurant is styled a bit like a diner, and it is quite loud inside. There is a bar area near the front then a decent amount of dining space in a rear room, but not incredibly spacious (perhaps understandable given that it is in the heart of Soho). The dishes are served in small sharing plates, so for a group of 5 we ordered a good 8-10 from all three sections of the menu. These then came in two separate courses, like you would for appetizers and mains, though they don't differ very much in size or anything. Standouts were the polenta Jerusalem style and the seared scallops. I really had my doubts about the polenta, as I generally don't enjoy it in a fine dining context, but with the truffle oil, you really can't think of anything else. And I was impressed with the portion size of the seared scallops - we ordered 2 dishes for 5 people but each plate came with 5 scallops so it was more than enough to go around. There was also a pork belly tajine that I thought was fantastic. All of us got a glass or two of wine and the bill actually came out to £40 a person, which I thought was extremely reasonable for dinner in Soho with drinks.

-oFsZW0Hl2sPOrGy5wJTgw.text: Timeout ranks it the 7th best restaurant in London (2014 Ranking). It doesn't disappoint.

8p-C6JesCFW-levX23Ps1g.text: Went here this week with the lovely Vicky L. We were going to go to another restaurant tonight but there was a 1.5 hour wait so she suggested this place. The food was absolutely delicious, it's been SO long since I've tasted such intense and fresh flavors, I'm not sure if I've ever tasted such good Polenta before and the deconstructed kebab was heavenly. The cocktails were small but hit the spot, i had the sipping gin infused with safron.

RoieVBaeb63QoIWhtndf_g.text: Been there already twice and I loved every minute and every bite! The combinations of the tastes are perfect, the service is amazing and you feel like you're the only one in the restaurant - and they don't kill you wallet at all! I will definitely go again

kGR9WEOp5990ZUBXp3o5RA.text: Excellent serendipitous find. Inventive cocktails. Tagine and oxtail not to be missed! Great vibe

2xNCWDL8hIA-L657cRcL_w.text: Best butternut squash risotto we ever had!!! This Israeli restaurant has the best food ever, wonderful chefs and Jason and Oliver were so welcoming to our party. We loved the atmosphere was so friendly and the company was great. We enjoyed our drinks, the polenta with mushrooms was also very good. Fantastic music and great atmosphere!! A must-do!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. A view of the front of the bar where we ate
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. A view from the bar looking down into the restaurant

_tfShAxM466ROkrpetHMOQ.text: A fantastic overall experience. The staff were lighthearted and extremely efficient. We arrived at 10pm on a Saturday night. The chef was singing along to the great music selection that they were playing at the perfect volume. The food was exceptional. My wife is vegetarian but she had no problem finding several great choices for herself. She loves it when she doesn't feel like she's had to compromise in her dinner selection  and this was definitely the case. I feel like I'm gushing and I guess I am. We'll be back for sure.

p4aJLId-IIltAzNGW0l5MQ.text: I've heard a few friends talk about this place but it's only after visiting it last night that I realise how amazing and accurate the reviews are.  I generally am a big fan of tapas style restaurants where u can try a bit of everything.  Dishes to try: polenta with truffle oil mushroom and Parmesan was the best dish of the day. Usually I don't like polenta but this was a definite exception. The bread and smoked aubergine taziki was great as well as the octo-hummus dish. I'll definitely visit again.

gF2889yZLZttC6k73yz39w.text: The food is beautiful. Reasonably priced, good portion size, fresh, different, flavoursome...I could go on. The service is prompt and to the point. The atmosphere is busy, the music a bit dodgy in my opinion but its clearly very popular overall. I'd like to come back and sit up at the bar, it was a little cramped in the seating areas.Liked it.

L8G3SfETrZLMUUebrNd4yg.text: As you know, I never give a restaurant 5 stars.  Palomar earns the 5th star.  Layo, the owner, has curated an amazing experience. We walked in at 5:30.  We did not want to leave, but we had theater tickets.  Start with the Music, standout. Chicago Blues to R&B, funk to rock, it melds forward and backward with a DJ's skill.  Sitting at the bar infront of the cocktail production is entertainment. Two young men, astutely aware of every bit of detail that a good cocktail demands.  I posted a video of our cocktails being made on my Instagram account.  Fresh middle eastern food, hence the name of the restaurant for the geographic area the food is selected from.  Try it all.  You won't be disappointed.  As you can see from the photo's, the food is artfully presented.  I hope I can get in again!

rxm1dAmXS05SEa9fQ2IvUg.text: Truly amazing food even for a foodie like me. We had several courses and all were excellent. Make sure you sit at the kitchen bar if you love to watch the head chef conduct his orchestra of star assistants. He inspects every dish and the service is lovely.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Coarse chopped chicken liver.
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Carpaccio of beet root
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. The charcoal oven. So cool! Called a Jasper

aPKk_0Ud4DRoJRSdC6eM5g.text: To be honest, there isn't a whole lot of words to sum up the quality of this place. You just have to make a booking and go. You pay for some of the best cuisine and dining in London. Its an obvious choice. If these Yelp reviews haven't made up your mind then you don't deserve The Palomar.

GaUBK2aEXoSr2F5Dr7uCvw.text: This place is amazing.  Please do NOT go so I can always get in and the buzz dies.  The bar is the place to be but not a great space for waiting so be forewarned.  Good staff and great service, amazing music.  My mind is exploding just thinking about the food there--everything will blow your mind.  It pains me to share this gem with the public, but need to keep my Gold Elite badge....so this is my community service for the year (if not the decade).

Sbv5T4OqkPnaoc_lL4SC1g.text: One word. Polenta. You'll be encouraged to get it and if you have even the slightly love of truffle it will delight you. Though it's near impossible to get a reservation at a decent time at Palomar, I'd say it's definitely worth booking ahead a few weeks in advance. Food: I'd  recommend starting with the mezze with side of special bread.  If you do that two mains is more than enough food. I wasn't a great fan of the scallops, though the Cornfed chicken was great. The oxtail stew is also nice, though the turnips add a bit of a bitter taste, depending on what you like. The bar area also appears to be super busy - in the future I may come just to nibble on the mezze with drinks. Service: I've now been to the Palomar twice. The first time I went with a girlfriend and our waiter was absolutely delightful - he came over often to check on us, gave us lots of recommendations and compliments of the chef and he was spot on regarding every dish - if it weren't for him I never would have tried to the polenta which I just can't say enough about.  The second time I went with my partner around 11PM after a West End Show (another plus is how late this place stays open and serving!) and service wasn't as great - it seemed more of a pain for parts of the menu to be explained to us whereas the first time he came over ready for recommendations.

l8xfGbZq9kcp0KaysKfhjw.text: I can't say enough good things about my experience. The food was phenomenal. I know everyone talks about the polenta, and it's great, but that butternut squash risotto was unlike any risotto I've ever had...and the fattoush salad. I mean, seriously. Combine the amazing food with great music and the singing and dancing chefs and you've got yourself a pretty perfect evening.

J2ji4Ttsa-iQnZbVFvPVtg.text: this place is legendary. small vibe and ambiance that is special. spicy plate if built for people who like spice...which is me. Jerusalem mix is a must same is the shakshukit. drinks are on fire as well. another LONDON must.

hf4FkZMx74mkdb5Jv8p0hA.text: FOODGASM (noun):  when the food is so good, you seriously think it was better than the best sex you ever had.The Palomar is definitely orgasmic.  Especially the Polenta.  The Polenta alone earned it like 10 billion stars.  It was by far the best polenta I've ever had in my life (a mixture of fluffy heaven paired with truffles, mushroom, what I am thinking is a mushroomy veloute-y brown pasty thing, asparagus and parmesan.  Served in a Mason Jar.  A Wooooooooow with 6 syllables.The bread and the "Daily 6" mezze starters were awesome too as were the 2 types of pickles they provided us with and the Fattoush (FYI it is big bits not little chopped up style swimming in herb salad but still yummy).  The Steak was only ok (I had a beef with the Latka as it was super thick and stodgy) and we were so full I didn't think we gave the deconstructed kebab a proper chance (it was quite tasty, really it was).Word of warning- the portions are HUGE.  For 2 hungry people, we shared the mezze starters, a bread, a salad, 2 meaty "mains" and a small pot of polenta.  We left most of the kebab (sad face) and about 1/3 of the salad as if we ate more we would have puked.  I would have be satisfied with just the starters, polenta and shared a dessert.  So, I personally think if you were going down our route, the mixed starters w/ bread, polenta and then just order the hot stuff dish by dish if you want dessert.  Otherwise I'd say 1 hot dish between 2 seems plenty.It's only in its early days yet and there were some kinks to iron out but they are pretty on top of things.  I heard one of the Chefs from Machneyuda (The owners) chiding a serving staff for not knowing exactly what they were serving.  At the moment, I think the original chefs from Machneyuda are in the shop for the opening as they were talking to lots of patrons, but with the quality of food served, I'm not worried that it will drop after they go home.*Machneyuda is apparently the hippest, most delicious and amazing restaurant in Jerusalem.  I won't know, I haven't been but this is the word on the proverbial internet street.**Extra bonus for the fact that this is part owned by Paskin siblings, who used to own the End.  I love that a pivotal part of me has also grown up from the days of Trash and transported to gastronomic paradise.

EWRrVed7GK_0-TY9TiihlQ.text: I absolutely love Israeli food, so was really excited to visit the Palomar which adds a modern take to fresh Middle Eastern cuisine. It looks so very lovely, and has a great vibe - although it was rather hot and sticky on this unusually warm summer London day. Foodwise, it was nice enough but think I may have missed something here given the glowing reviews.  The food just didn't hit the spot for me. Maybe I like my Israeli food boring and traditional.  We started with the beatroot with goats cheese which was amazing. Some of the daily 6 assorted mezze dips we ordered were surprisingly a bit bland - especially the marrow dip blah.  I was expecting wonders from the polenta reviews on here but it was too cheesey for meThe malabi Rose-scented milk pudding for dessert went down a storm though.Overall I wasn't bowled over but it was a pleasant experience and I'd definitely come back to give it another go. I'd make a point to request to sit at the bar as that seems a bit more atmospheric than being crammed in at the back.As a footnote I might add considering the place is owned by the guys who ran the End (a night club were I spent much of my 20 somethings), I would have expected to hear something better than Blurred lines from the sound system!

o2W8xcA6QXCveDz_v5q6RA.text: Fabulous restaurant with small plate menu. Make a reservation or wait. Try to sit at the bar where you can watch the talented team do the magic. From appetizer to main to pudding, everything was delicious.

GXYUMArOLM67Qj2Bfz9ESw.text: Some of the best food I've had, in a relaxed and fun atmosphere. Everything is super fresh and flavorful. The service is great as well.

OM3wo7R1IUs9OhX48oz-Eg.text: Manager could do standup comedy (probably does). Food is amazing and beautifully presented, staff is incredibly friendly, atmosphere is warm and playful. A Must.

f73GrqXYb7HPynzp5ZkUIw.text: Best food in London and good value tooThe kinoa dish with truffle oil was to die for...all is fresh and flavours that explode in your mouth Everything fresh and creativeAtmosphere is friendly, cool and non presumptuous Book ahead...

vxisWhFHopx0Imv-QR47og.text: We found Palomar using YELP while visiting London. When the waiter learnt that it was our first time in the restaurant he described the menu as 'New Jerusalem Cuisine' influenced by - and he named - half a dozen Mediterranean countries. What a wonderful meal!! Everything we put in our mouths was excellent, well balanced, some of them new taste experiences. Staff very attentive and friendly. No doubt, we give 5 of 5 stars.

RAzwKDjpV7UyRB61FVdq1Q.text: Funky, daring, great atmosphere! Service was quick, efficient and friendly! Great wine list...we had the Riesling Rolly Gassman and Ribolla - Princic. The Riesling went extremely well with the Endive and Chickory salad, the orange wine with the Pork Belly... Scallops a bit disappointing, but overall a great experience!

C3LO0VIDruokumutG0Yadg.text: I'm going to tell you a story. A story about what it's like in the restaurant called Palomar. I'm going to start off by telling you that this experience wasn't just walking off the street and hoping for a table, but it was based on a reservation that I had made two months prior. Two months. So I arrive before the four other people that I had booked for. We had a table for five. They show me to our table. In order to get to our table, I had to squeeze my way past the people eating at the bar and standing behind the bar waiting for a seat. There's a bar area that was clearly made for dining, and there's really only (barely) room for a single person to fit behind them. However, there is already an entire line of people standing behind them, so I was forced to shove my way through the crowd of people to get to the dining area in the back of the restaurant. I can only imagine what it must be like for diners eating at the bar area, as their backs must be constantly shoved by people trying to squeeze through the miniscule space to go from the door to the back of the restaurant. I get to our table. It's a round table in a corner of banquette seating with one extra chair. For five people. They probably could have put an extra chair around the table except there was another round table shoved directly up next to our table. So there was just barely room for people to squeeze through the two tables to get to the banquette seating. So now they've clearly squeezed five people around a table for four. For a reservation that I made two months prior. It's not as if I walked in and said "Hey we can make it work". No I booked a table at a restaurant two months prior in order to have a nice meal with some friends, and they've shoved us around a tiny table. I mean the table is tiny and really should only have four people, but possibly could have had five if there was room for two chairs, but no, only one. So when the rest of my party arrives, one of them has to physically sit with her legs across her boyfriend's lap in order for the five of us to squeeze around the table.We're looking at the menu and deciding what to order. The server seems to just answer questions to what he wants and not to what we're asking. Strange. We're trying to decide what to order. I keep asking my partner what he wants, and he responds with "whatever". I finally look at him and ask, "what's wrong?" and he responds, "I don't want to eat here". Our friend sitting next to him smiles, looks at him and exclaims, "I thought I was the only one". So we decided to get up and leave and go someplace else. Good thing the service was slow because all we had at that point was water, and we hadn't ordered drinks or anything (although it felt like it had been 10-15 minutes). So we shoved our way back through the bar area in order to leave. Apparently the toilets aren't much better as the urinals are directly underneath the sinks or something. I don't understand how a place like this could open up as the layout must be a fire hazard. I'm pretty sure I need to report them to the fire inspector, as if there was a fire in the restaurant I'm sure everyone would be trapped inside or crushed trying to get out the extremely narrow area in and out of the restaurant. Maybe the food is great, but given the severe lack of concern about their customers personal space or safety, I'm not sure how anyone could ever eat here.

cFoAyZM8ulK3pIyidoeSxQ.text: One of the best meals I've had in London. Really perfectly prepared and presented and lovely house wine. The staff there was also very friendly and super prompt. We went in just before a movie and they made sure that we were done with dinner in 40 minutes!

KZSF7-DKhV-loprhmW0wng.text: Great service. Unique flavors. Fun atmosphere. Try this if you are looking for good food with a diner feel. Don't be afraid to sit and the bar and right in front of the chef.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

BzGobLQ29JzIIF07sl9iDQ.text: The dishes were just so memorable!! My friend is a local and I was visiting. Turned out we both had this restaurant in mind, and getting to try it together for the first time was awesome :)Salmon or beef  tartare? GET BOTH!!!Mushroom asparagus Polenta? Maybe order 2! Or one for each person at the table! I had to use all my will power from stuffing my face into that tiny pot to get the last bit of polenta Rose pudding: it was hard to follow the others - but the dessert held its own

rvuVP0YShawQ1e-VgUp7ZA.text: This deserves more than 5 stars.Although the portions/plates are to small and food too good to be shared.

g7moJA4tTYL8Q04bAakD6g.text: i absolutely loved everything about this restaurant. the food, the vibe, and the service were all top notch. the beetroot dish was amazing and i also really liked the scallops, but everything we had was good. sitting at the bar and watching the chefs make the food really added to the experience. i also liked the music and fun vibe of the place. our waiter helped us decide on some dishes and checked in with us often to ensure we were taken care of. if i visit london again i will definitely come here again.

dQjXieuiF5ga-40P4JpTqA.text: This restaurant is truly amazing! New special everyday and everything is fresh! The staff is very well trained and friendly. The cocktails are great I would recommend the pallor one which was my favourite.I had such a nice experience there and the place is perfect for date or going by yourself ( if alone sit at the bar and you will have fun ) I can't wait to be back

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

8a-FJYWQ1qHLOZPwyKXqaw.text: Quick glance:+ great food served on stunning crockery+ knowledgeable staff+ great buzz for sharing with a friend+ mmm, cocktail- long queueFull review:What a mix of fantastic food, not only prepared and cooked beautifully but served in a mix of decorative plates and containers. The restaurant is hugely popular and has a waiting list of about 1-2 months if you want to book in advance to dine at one of their tables at the back. My friend and I decided to chance it one weeknight and waited about an hour for a spot to dine at the bar. It's not so bad though; turn up early in the evening (or very late), hand over your mobile number and go shopping/drinking nearby. When a spot frees up ,the restaurant gives you a call so you can claim your position. The bar itself is a little packed, but it's buzzing with atmosphere. Not great for groups but the set up is perfect for catching up with a friend or for a casual date. I was most impressed with the staff's knowledge and friendliness, who was able - and willing - to go into details of every dish and even make hearty recommendations for first time visitors like myself. The dining experience is all about sharing: pick 4-6 dishes for two people and you can sample a variety of dishes. The portion sizes look small but are deceptively filling. My advice: make sure to save room for dessert; the chocolate fudge was heavenly. And give the cocktail a try!

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Beef from the special menu with fried gnocchi
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Chicken with Jerusalem mixed spice, Swiss chard and freekeh
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Dining at the bar at the Palomar Restaurant

hDJGZWmsjQkMdUqCkDkVXA.text: Loved it.Went here for lunch today with a PR exec client, as I've heard constant chattering that it's one of London's hottest restaurants.  Though the fun and vivacious atmosphere pertained specifically to dinner, I immediately saw the potential when I walked in.  The vibe, the slick 30's decor, the jazz-funk soundtrack, the open kitchen bar (where I sat): all lovely.  I didn't take one bite and I already wanted to return.My client and I shared:Kabaneh ('potted' bread with tahini and velvet tomato sauces): Airy and excellent.Shredded Lamb and Gnocchi, the day's special: lamb was so soft and tasty, gnocchi was delicious, but definitely needed to cut back on the saltSalmon Tartare With aubergine 2 ways. yoghurt, pine nuts & parsley: WOW.  Never did I think aubergine would upstage the taste of salmon, but the Palomar managed.  Small portion but was absolutely delicious.Polenta Jerusalem style Asparagus, mushroom ragout, parmesan & truffle oil: Like everyone on this Yelp page (and every food critic) has said...it's a MUST-TRY.  I could eat 3 of them.  One of my favorite dishes in the last few months.Octo-hummous Josperised Octopus "steak" Chickpea Msabacha & cherry tomato confit: not sure if you should take my word for it, but this was the most disappointing dish for me, by far.  Granted, I'm not a huge fan of hummus...but I was secretly hoping Palomar could convert me with their innovative version.  Oh well :/For dessert:Malabi Rose-scented milk pudding, raspberry coulis, coconut meringue pistachio crunch, fresh raspberries & kataifi: meh...was a bit disappointed with this as well, perhaps too much coconut shavings.  The food I tried was not perfect, but the vast majority was DAMN good.  I do have a bit of beef with the prices, though: some of these small plates were £12 (octo-hummus) and wouldnt get me full if I had 3 of the same...thank God the meal was covered by the client ;)  But if you're not really concerned about budget then I'd highly recommend The Palomar!

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. yum: today's special of gnocchi and shredded lamb
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Octo-hummus
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. MUST-TRY: Jerusalem polents

zIpffOW0sObDffSIVo2N7w.text: Friendly vibe and service, excellent middle eastern cuisine, and reasonable prices.  You should definitely order the gnocchi, which goes perfectly with a nice cocktail.  The "Palomar Restaurant" was made popular by the novel epicsaga - Infinity, in which it is featured.

SnUEQ_S6RxIybNYyVlNBIw.text: Came here with two friends while in London for work and loved absolutely everything we had. We were nervous about whether we would get a table but fortune favored us and we were seated right away despite not having a reservation. The spicy experience(?) was so delicious - I literally put it on everything else! The scallops, deconstructed kebab (the pita that came with was to die for!), fattoush salad, trout, baba ganoush and the polenta were outstanding and then we topped it off with the petit fours which was a great sampling - perfect to satisfy the sweet tooth without over-indulging. The service was also fantastic, our waiter -- charming young man originally from York -- was engaging and very helpful with his suggestions, all of which were spot on. It was our friend's bday (something the hostess overheard us saying when she seated us), not only did our waiter proactively wish her happy bday but they included a bday candle with the petit fours. Really sweet and unexpected touch that was greatly appreciated.

xR9hoOVkU1JWnbJJbLFgmg.text: I love this place!!The chef is the greatest. Very friendly staff and the food is out of this world .

43Qi4_9OZgCixtMkZkuC_w.text: We came for lunch. Amazing atmosphere. If you want a modern twist on cuisine from tel aviv look no further. And don't miss out on the ribeye steak. One of the best I've ever had. The seats at the bar are the best if you want a special experience. The cooks are very laid back and fun to watch. You can tell they love their job and their food.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

lnz9nQW4cMnfu7AC6D2Dvg.text: Great Mediterranean, Israeli inspired food! Had the pleasure of sitting at the kitchen bar and watched the chefs at work. Lamb sweetbreads were phenomenal! Highly recommended, go for lunch to beat the crowds. Service matched the high quality of food.

gkTmkKH8k8G2fuQ1T6uodg.text: So many reviews can't be wrong..This place is seriously good.Totally recommend sitting at the bar, seems the kind of place you should drop in for a bite and a glass whenever you're in the area.Highlights included the yemeni bread, scallop, beef tatare and the stilton cheesecake.Go.

Gsg3uGmNhsKrbDrRMvRzVA.text: One of the most exciting dining experiences I've had in a loooong time! I mean, not only are you perched up at the dining bar reveling in plate after plate of super colorful, wildly spiced and inventive dish after dish, you also get treated to spontaneous blessings by chef Tomer and his team in Hebrew during your meal! Israeli chef Tomer isn't introducing his guests to his creative twist on Israeli cooking, he's serving them an amped up, adrenaline filled dose of his homeland. At Palomar Tomer works with an artillery of spices, tinctures, and glazes to transform typical dishes into true works of irreverant art. Tomer was cooking right in front of us and basically took our order into his hands, giving us spoonfulls of things to try as we waited for the next round, explaining how he made his caramels and spice blends, and transforming some of the raw items into pregnant-friendly dishes (he poached the scallops in oil and grilled my tataki meat for me so that I could partake in the festivities -- a real mensch as we say in yiddish!). Highlights included the fish falafel, beef tataki, decontructed kebab, crab-filled kreplach in a rich broth, and the carrot cake for dessert which is made by Tomer's pastry chef wife. A truly exceptional meal in an exciting, fun, personality-charged restaurant. Reserve a spot at the back at the bar where Tomer presides so that you watch the rising star in action.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Sumac lemonade with chef Tomer on The background
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Chefs delight
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

uFopLieZwStHnEFJKD7E4w.text: went for dinner after Les Mis in early august. meal and service were absolutely fantastic. aubergines were incredible, as was the haloumi. all in all, a great experience and would highly recommend.

QQtlsMLiA9ill_NsH-0tDg.text: The food is pretty dope.  I'd just been eating at a place in ny called balaboosta for Mod-Is (modern israeli) and was gonna platz when i found out about palomar. the food was dope, the vibe was pretty dope, and the wait was not so dope but they let you leave and wait at this weird pub next door which is like totally chain pub but imagine someone spent like £2,000,000 on decor, i mean polished brassed up something dope.only thing i fucking hated were the olives but so blahzay ab that kinda thing, just rolls right off me.

zAV6Wyt9Tpw7K7sVt2Vydw.text: We decided that our meal here ranks among our best ever!The food was fantastic, brilliant for veggies and meat lovers alike and bursting with flavour. The vibe in the restaurant was so buzzy and very fun. Cocktails were good - Garden of Eden my fav. We were going to go to Nopi but it was full and decided to try here over Honey & Co. We're so very glad we did, as the night was just fabulous. Recommend the bar seats for the full experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Tomer drumming
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Dessert
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Birthday celebrations

LFbG2tqF0eB3g5B0XfsP8Q.text: Amazing place.  We had reservations for noon, just as it opened, and sat at the chef's counter.  Fantastic experience and absolutely delicious food.  I can't even begin to remember all that we had and we kept ordering more when we saw new dishes being prepared.  Would happily go here again any day.  Not a cheap lunch but well worth the price.

0TiUA53yUeHfLj4-Y73lRw.text: One of the best meals I've had in a long while:1) Kubaneh - soft and warm, with yummy dipping sauce.2) Spiced Olives - served slightly warm, fall right off the pit, in a delicious marinade.3) Fattoush salad - I've had a LOT of Lebanese food in my day, and Fattoush salads are a favorite. This is far and away the best I've ever had. Instead of baked pita chips, there were more traditional croutons. The bowl had a smear of tahini / yogurt, and the flavor of the dressing was perfect. Everything about this salad was awesome.4) Polenta Jerusalem style (wife) - I tasted it, and it is one of the creamiest and most flavorful polenta's I've ever had.5) Pork Belly Tajine - round cut of pork belly - fell apart at the first touch with the fork. Very flavorful.6) Chocolate Crémeux - if you like chocolate, get this. Awesome.7) Balevenie 14y Caribbean Cask Scotch - yummy paired with the Chocolate. If you can get a reservation, you need to get to this place ASAP!

NZ_M6EBg1XpsqT1jFOzSGQ.text: Probably one of my best meal in London. it's not cheap, but it's really worth it.To start, the service was fantastic. The waiter explained us the menu in detail and also asked for any food allergies. When I told him I couldn't eat liquorice he went and check which dish might have some. Very thorough.Then the food. We ordered kubaneh to start (a sort of fluffy brioche) because the neighbour table had it. Then our neighbour saw it on our table and order it, as did the table next to them.The kubaneh chain reaction. Cod falafels, chicken liver, pulled lamb tagliatelle, deconstructed kebabs, everything was delicious. They also have an oyster bar (although we were too full to try them) Amazing place, perfect for a date.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Kubaneh - you must try this.
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

Zw8E3hRNencESzadeykBPA.text: I went here for dinner before a show and highly recommend it if you are looking for a meal before a show, too. We split 6 dishes and they were all great! We made a reservation and were seated immediately. We had the babaganoosh, salad, bread, beef, beets and pasta- all great!

ebqF-7UycfY8WnQPBf4u9Q.text: This is both one of the hottest and controversial Restos for middle eastern food. Barbary its slightly wallet friendlier sister resto seems to generate more consistent reviews. However, our experience for the quality of food certainly exceeded the superb experience we had at Barbary. Service was friendly as well. Cannot make reservations other than for the noon and 5pm seating around the kitchen bar. There is a seating area beside the kitchen bar area which might be easier to score on a busy night. However, leave your name with hostess and they'll call you. While you wait to be called go have a nice glass of Rioja at the Mas Q Menos nearby in what is otherwise a touristy area.

14Tr2fkyx6Z2i5pgrYBPgA.text: Cool New Israel restaurant. Don't worry, they are liberal and even serve pork belly. Some dishes taste a bit similar to each other, though. Friendly staff. This addition to the West Bank of Chinatown is welcome!

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

bKDm9E_vWdFWfWf9uk586g.text: Such an amazing find in London!! The food, the vibe, the service, and drinks are all delicious!! We sat at the bar and were able to interact with the friendly staff and watch the kitchen prepare the food. The music is also on point. Would absolutely recommend this spot and plan on returning here!

lpE861Ddt_IOGH1jSSzN1Q.text: OMG! You all have to plug it in for your next visit... I am full and yet there is a taste for more... WOW! And Ross is a superb host!

e9iVqG8ayTbBzxLYsLExIg.text: Drinks, food, wonderful.I started with the Red Mamba cocktail (special), a mix of gin and whisky, which is served is a homemade parmigiano crouton. They recommend you alternate between both. I couldn't stop, finish the cocktail in 5 minutes. Absolutely delicious.Followed with the Kubaneh, as an appetizer. It is a greatly individually baked pita bread loaf, v tahini and velvet tomatoes, to dip. Wonderful, best tahini I've had, and the bread is fresher then fresh.I then completed with the gnocchi. Far from the Italian dish, the fried little potato bites we served over a wonderful mix of leaves, almonds and cheese. I come to London every two years or so, for business. I'll be back here, no doubt.

2DvFtTlzyE1IZEy0fJrSyg.text: Outstanding middle eastern cuisine, in a unique setting with wonderful service at a very reasonable price.  That really is a pretty good summary of this restaurant.  They had every aspect covered and it made for a great experience even when dining alone.As far as recommended choices on this great menu, the octopus dish is an absolute must try, as is the gnocchi. The bread is good but personally I wouldn't fill up with on it.  Their tomato, almond and crouton salad is wonderful and should be tried for sure.  The Jerusalem mix is very flavorful but didn't have enough meat for me and I had to pick it around a mountain of onions.The drinks are great!  My favorite was the bumble bee, refreshing, flavorful and expertly made.Loved this place!

754FWi_JPSwVkLUEVMIRJQ.text: Ummm authentic Mediterranean food. Absolutely delicious this was a real surprise here in London. The food in England has progressively gotten better and better in the past couple decades so it's no surprise you're fine great fare.

iaXlDL5ZmJSnwKhV3wv9BQ.text: We had the great pleasure of after-theater dining tapas-style at the Palomar on the evening of April 10.  Cozy vibe, eclectic patrons and top notch service from Alina (I hope I spelled her name correctly) and the most delicious and well-prepared food.Like many folks, we started with the Kubaneh - freshly baked bread with tahini and velvet tomato dips.  I've never had tahini that was so silky in texture.  OMG.  Heaven from the first bite.We followed that with Shakshukit, Polenta Jerusalem Style and the Josperised Aubergine.  All of them delicious and perfectly prepared.And did I mention the great service?  :-)

wJT12JjZDJDzdOR_Jg2iDg.text: Fabulous trendy little bar/restaurant in the heart of the West End serving a range of varied tapas style dishes based on Mediterranean /Middle Eastern cuisine. Food, service and atmosphere are excellent but you might have to queue to get in.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

mhCfTJpRtUo7qgwT9kTpbg.text: It's been awhile since we have been completed 'wowed' with great food! The first hurdle, was booking a table 3 weeks ahead. Yes that's right, we had to book 3 weeks ahead for a table! That goes to show just how popular Palomar is.The best way to describe the food at the Palomar is: tapas, modern Jerusalem style. Why? Because most of the items on the menu are little sharing plates. Based on what we ate, they all compliment each other and you'll be amazed at how many different combinations you can form with the plates you ordered.We had:Kubaneh (£6.00) - this is a loaf of Yemeni bread baked in a pot and it's served with a tahini and a tomato dipThe Spicy Experience (£3.50) - this is a must order for you spicy fans! As the name suggests, it's a small plate of different kinds of spices:Polenta Jerusalem Style (£9.50) - hands down, the best polenta.Fattoush Salad (£8.50) - a simple salad of tomato and cucumber with not so simple flavours! Seasoned with  za'atar, sumac, massive chunkcs of pita croutons and brazil nutsShakshukit (£12.00) - described as a deconstructed kebab. Layered minced meat, yoghurt, tahini, "The 4 tops" (which we think are the drizzles of different toppings) and Yaeli's pita.Pork Belly Tajine (£17.00) - A super tender pork belly (with all the lovely fatty bits intact) with Ras el Hanout, dried apricots, dried fig and Israeli couscous (giant cous cous). Fish of the day (£18.00) - the fish we had that day was cod. The cod was thickly cut and cooked perfectly - crispy skin and moist flesh. Carrot Cake (£7.00) - this was said to be a must try if we went to Palomar. The carrot cake itself was pretty traditional, having all the usual flavours (mixed spice, cinnamon, ginger).Jerusalem Mess (£11.00) - THE MUST HAVE! If you know what an Eton Mess is, then this is the Jewish equivalent - labneh mousse, almond crumble, strawberries, lemon cream, elderflower and apple jelly & fresh sorrel. The creamy mousse had a very subtle sweetnessIt's definitely a must go if you visit London and really don't mind the price to have really awesome meal. Definitely one of best we have eaten!

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Shakshukit (12.00) - described as a deconstructed kebab.

mGvLCuqIa05-1PnUTnV2QQ.text: Everything we had was fantastic.  The beetroot and goats cheese, with the beetroot in a half-way between cooked and turned-into-jam state, the hazlenuts and cheese slightly charred.  And the fish casserole, with perfect fish in a tomato sauce (tho were warned it was spicy and it totally wasn't at all).  And the pork tagine, which we were not warned was spicy and had a slight kick (well more than the fish did) and was probably the best thing of an everything-was-fabulous meal.  It's not cheap and it's always busy.  But it's worth the wait and the price  We were sat at the bar, and the dishes came as they were ready, which is ideal because we got them freshly cooked. The guy serving us (Omer) was great too, tho I feel he slightly misled us on portion size, on his advice we ended up ordering 4 small dishes and 2 large dishes for two people, and we were totally stuffed.  But there's nothing I'd drop from that order, and we didn't have to finish it but we chose to, so it seems churlish to complain.    I ate at a lot of good places this trip to London, several of which were 5* worthy (foxlow, lahore one), but the palomar was the best.

aR49OEC8AvqKMbBguZdcOQ.text: The best meal I had on my recent trip to London.  Excellent cocktails, incredible food.  Don't miss the incredible polenta dish or the chopped liver appetizer (pure heaven)!  Perfect place to come before or after a show in SoHo.

8uLACtx6AQWJda0DhS4Evw.text: The perfect meal to end my last night in London! My party of two had reservations in the dining room for 9:30pm, but we were in the neighborhood early and they kindly sat us at the bar at 7:30pm. We were luckily enough to sit right in front of the head chef, which was an experience in itself. He was friendly and kept the conversation going with us all night! He gave us recommendations on what to order, and we were not disappointed! We ordered:- Chef's Nishnoush (4): A small starter which was mini. There was half a slice of pita to dip the accompanying sauces, but I would opt for the Kubaneh instead if I was to pick a bread.- Kubaneh (6): You must order this baked Yemen bread in a pot! The bread is so soft and buttery, which melts in your mouth and is perfect to accompany all the dishes! - Salmon Tartare (9): The portion was actually very meager, and nothing too out of the ordinary. If you have tried salmon tartare before then this won't be anything too novel.- Shashukit (12): A medley of minced meats with pita. It was very flavorful and one of my favorites! Must-try!- Polenta Jerusalem Style (9.5): I'm not a fan of polenta, but this was great! The added mushrooms and asparagus was a good balance to avoid making the dish too heavy! - Pork Belly Tanjine (17): This dish was large in portion! The pork belly was melt in your mouth delicious! For a party of two, this was more than enough food. We were struggling to finish the food. The portions may be small, but the small amounts of food and the bread definitely fill you up!

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Shakshukit
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Polenta Jerusalem Style
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Salmon Tartare

pjmSZCV0LpEdCWoDzK5ifQ.text: Quite good food with a high tempo, happening vibe. Eclectic, varied, worth trying. I can't remember what else I liked but I can post this review without writing more.

qg7PhaExfk3WAgZYb24x_Q.text: I had lunch here on my birthday this year. Having read glowing reviews from critics, I thought it was worth a try, especially as I hadn't had Israeli food much before. It's cool to eat somewhere that has a branch in another countryI snagged a seat at the kitchen counter where I could watch the new chefs being put through their paces. My excellent waitress helped me to choose the right amount of foodI started with 2 oysters, topped with coriander, lemon and harissa oil. Zingy and he briny oyster came through wellNext was shakshukit - a deconstructed kebab with yoghurt, tahini and 4 tops. I enjoyed this but wasn't sure the deconstruction added much to the flavour profileI was surprised to see pork belly on the menu - my waitress confirmed the restaurant wasn't fully kosher! The pork belly came with tagine, ras El hanout and dried apricot and Israeli couscous. Unfortunately, the belly was a little dryI finished off with Malabi, a rose-scented milk pudding that the chef topped off with a birthday candleThere are so many more interesting sounding dishes on the menu that I want to go back and try

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

csbqKUEL5zeu4nQSOm91mA.text: The vibe, the ambiance, the food and the venue are all great. The final two dishes of Pork Belly Tagine and the Jerusalem Mess were delightful too. The Pork was cooked well and as a Tagine style dish, it is all about slow cooking. The glazed carrot and dry fruit were welcome friends to the pork and prevented the dish from becoming too samey. The final Sweets, the Jerusalem Mess was a great surprise. The moose, the crumble and the sorrel were all so good. The crunch, the cold, the freshness and the sweetness most importantly made me absolutely stuffed.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Josper Octopus

9Z3Ycgkc1UpPT_bxCQjHXQ.text: I normally do not write bad reviews cannot be bothered unless it is really really bad. The host is god awful I cannot even describe how rude, impolite, and unprofessional HE is. This place is not going to go far and is going to become OLD news with such poor reception and host. Not worth trying so many excellent restaurants in London that can provide better experience try The Barbary.

nspoTvhWo-um0a8e3MQzOw.text: Such a fabulous meal... I was a solo traveler and I was made feel right at home. The "bar" is certainly the best option, even if you are not a solo traveler but not good for more than 3, at most. Make sure to make a reservation because it filled up FAST.

2fRxVwLCu3zBrENhztm3_Q.text: A couple of things to keep in mind with this review:1) It has been exactly one year since we dined here during our trip to London (thanks Timehop)2) we didn't have reservations so the wait was long (like ~2 hours which we killed by walking around)3) It has been one of our *all-time* favorite meals we have had in all our travels so farWith that said I can't recall each dish but the plates are small and meant to be shared. My husband and I often joke that we'd come back to London just to have their food all over again. So do yourself a favor and stop in if you're in the area, because I'm jealous you can and I can't.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

QVunNcdSJkclWgYVLrif9g.text: If I could rate this 6 stars, I would! Every bite of my baba ganoush, Octo hummus, and Palomar glida was deliciously flavorful and all the chefs and servers were lovely. No one was pushy despite the immense crowds and I got served almost immediately after ordering. Will be back next week     ,!

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Octo hummus-- melts in your mouth
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Baba ganoush with cucumber substitute for pita
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Glida -- three scoops of three most delicious ice cream I've ever had

deThcS4AGAKyiQNicUGWRg.text: I was traveling for business and wanted a fun place to dine. The Palomar has great vibes and busy, even on a Monday night. There was a 45 min wait but I was dining alone so able to get a seat at the bar. The menu is small plate style but very accommodate for 1 person as they can split many of the plates!!  The food is middle eastern inspired, well-prepared! The service is friendly and quick. Cocktails are fun and delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

3JlUuZpyOIJ1mA9m-m4vcA.text: This place was simply incredible. We were able to squeeze in a reservation for as soon as they opened. The restaurant is small but cozy and clean. The waitstaff were attentive. We ordered a number of starters as well as some larger plates. Everything started coming out and we were blown away. The baba ganouj was to die for, as well as the puffy bread with tomato sauce and tahini. Finally the duck leg confit, and the ground lamb dishes were incredible. We stuffed our faces. I thought they were going to have to bring a gurney to get me out of there. We were not disappointed by a long shot. It was absolutely amazing and we would definitely go back if we were ever in London again. I cannot recommend it enough. I really wish we had a great Israeli restaurant near us in the states. I highly recommend you try it out.

3YyywzsoVerfzcQMRBPmSg.text: Recently ate here on a trip to London.  Much smaller place than I expected. Service was fairly attentive and food was very good.  Everything is shared and brought as it is ready.  We tried a selection of dips,Tzatziki, Taramasalata and Baba Ganoush. All were very good. Also did glazed chicken livers and duck confit, as well as beets and "Tree of Life" broccoli.  I didn't think the livers or duck were standouts but they were tasty enough. Cocktails were good.  My expectations were maybe for something a little less chaotic so that probably colored my impression.  I will say, and not to sound like a grumpy old man, but this was one of the loudest, most cramped restaurants I have been to in a while, in one of the busiest neighborhoods in London (at least on a Saturday night).  I was hoping for something more like Zahav in Philadelphia, but this was definitely more casual and, for me, a little too much sensory overload from the noise, crowds and loud music.  That's not the restaurant's fault, so just putting this out there so anyone reading knows what to expect.

NI_91wQQKWwWIEG6VcYy2A.text: Located in the heart of Soho, The Palomar serves food of modern day Jerusalem with a twist. Their menu is comprised of trendy small plates that are made to share and worthy of the 'gram. The restaurant only takes reservations for 12:00pm and 5:00pm seatings at the kitchen bar. If you are unable to snag a booking, I strongly recommend coming early to avoid the 1-2 hour wait. Trust me, it will be worth it. Every single dish we ordered deserved 5 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Kubaneh (6) - Yemeni pot baked bread served with tahini & velvet tomatoes
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Malabi (7) - hibiscus syrup & Iranian pistachios
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Josperised Aubergine (7) - feta emulsion, tomato, fresh oregano, crispy shallots & pine nuts

MouclO1Rx0qD4kV2aGi-rg.text: Ambiance is simply epic. Loud, but cool and friendly and simply welcoming. The food is outstanding. It really is. I expected this based on the reviews but damn... It's really good!! The open kitchen allows you to really see how everyone is, and the attitude is simply amazing... People love love working here. The drinks? Wow they are also epic. Not expected! I see the menu and what they offer and I was like 'errrrrrr is this a cocktail bar?'. Overall... Simply amazing. This is a 5 star all the way around! Just an update... Been back 8 times now... it's always epic. Every single time!

AboSvvjzc--DvV6YfBSKPQ.text: The Palomar Restaurant was our last stop in during our trip in London, and it turned out to be the perfect choice. This is definitely one of those restaurants where everything on the menu is very well-prepared, so it's hard to go wrong with any one particular dish.We ordered: - Kubaneh: Yemeni pot baked bread served with tahini & velvet tomatoes. Great starter dish but make sure to share with at least one other person or else you'll be too full.- Fattoush Salad: tomato, cucumber, za'atar, sumac, challag croutons, Brazil nuts and labneh. Refreshing and balanced some of the richer dishes.- Shakshukit: deconstructed kebab with minced beef & lamb, yoghurt, tahini, cured lemon & harissa. Interesting concept and solid flavors, but didn't blow us away like the other dishes.- Polenta Jerusalem Style with asparagus, mushroom ragout, parmesan & truffle oil. Super rich and savory - would definitely order again.- Gnocchi Hamousta: fennel & leek cream, almonds & ricotta salata. Unique dish that was well-prepared.- Jerusalem Mess: Labneh mousse, almond crumble, strawberries, lemon cream & fresh sorrel. The perfect end to a wonderful meal!Overall, each dish was amazing, but the combination of everything was a little too rich for us and we ended up a bit too full. If we went back, I would probably substitute the gnocchi or the shakshukit with a lighter dish. Make sure to make reservations for this restaurant. I made reservations 3 weeks prior and a lot of the times were already booked.

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. The Palomar
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Jerusalem Mess: Labneh mousse, almond crumble, strawberries, lemon cream & fresh sorrel
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Shakshukit: deconstructed kebab with minced beef & lamb, yoghurt, tahini, cured lemon & harissa

xFH67_sc9pDuLt6c8pZNmw.text: Last trip to London I managed 11 Michelin stars in a week, so it felt natural for my first meal on this trip to be here. It didn't disappoint. Moroccan/ middle Eastern fare was on the menu. Lots of small plates, none of them any short of delicious. Octo hummus, falafel, duck, chicken, and sirloin were just a few of the standout dishes I remember, but honestly, everything was good. Don't hesitate about coming here, if you can get a booking.

ZLHF9y1KZniogvSL0cYlIA.text: Amazing!!!!!!! So delicious! Set in front of chef Shai, and it made the whole evening even better. The food is outstanding! Service is great and overall fun place to go to. I loved every bite of everything we ate. We had the fried fish, the octopus, cubena, eggplant, humus, polenta, cream- some desert, few cocktails. Go!

HB_Ovce361yw77JgmzO14A.text: I loved every bite and sip at this place. We got the Spicy experience, the tzazki, the Moroccan mussels (they were a special), the pita, and the sea bass. All were something unique and special! The drinks are tasty and well balanced!! The hospitality also kicked ass. The host is so nice and smooth in handling a busy restaurant. He politely explained how long the wait was and sat as soon as he could. The bartenders were so friendly and chatted with us as if they had us in their home. We dined up to closing time and one of the severs was having her own drink after her shift. I asked what she got and after telling me about it, she went and got a cup to give me a taste. That was so kind of her and thoughtful. It's fun running into genuinely friendly people.The bar is sexy and hits all the sense. The music was also great. Love, love and love this place. Just go. Good luck getting a spot!

yQCDhQ6_PRBpWczCreFlfA.text: One of my top 3 restaurants in London - I've eaten at the sister restaurant, Barbary, about 5 times now and I can't get enough of it and I've now eaten here 3 times, it's one of my favorites. My only regret about Palomar is not coming here sooner.It's hard to get a reservation here, but they do have walk-in seating at the bar, so if you come early enough when they open you may not have to wait, or if you come during dinner-time, expect a 1-2 hour wait. I wouldn't come past 8 pm since they probably will be done taking names for the dinner service.The menu changes quite frequently depending on the season and what is fresh, but the following always seems to be on the menu - I've gone multiple times over the course of a year and these things seem to be staples.Kubaneh Bread, tomato, tahini (£6.40) - This is a bit expensive for bread, but it comes out fresh from the oven and is light, fluffy and remissent of brioche. It comes with a tomato sauce and a tahini sauce, both of which are delicious paired with the bread. I almost always get this when I bring someone new to the restaurant for their first time.Burnt Courgette Tzatziki Mint, garlic, sumac (£4.30) - This dip goes really well with the bread, so if you get the bread, get this as well! It almost tastes a little fizzy / effervescent and it's one of my favorite dips.Octo Hummus Chickpea msabacha, aubergine (£13.80) - This octopus is really delicious, it's grilled and served with a chickpea mash. I almost always get this as well.Shakshukit Beef, lamb, pistachios, pine nuts (£12.50) - This is like a deconstructed kebab. It was good, but I preferred the other dishes more. I got it on the first time I went here but haven't gotten it on subsequent visits.Fattoush Salad Tomatoes, cucumber, sumac (£9.80) - This salad is fresh and tasty with amazing croutons, and very flavorful from the sumac. This is worth getting; if you're only 2 people you can get a half portion so you can get other things.Polenta Mushrooms, asparagus, truffle (£9.80) - This is good but pretty rich and very heavy on the truffle. It's good for a few bites but it was almost a little too heavy for me. Ricotta gnocchi in a fennel cream sauce - They always have a rotating pasta dish on the menu (or 2) and this ricotta gnocchi was delicious and one of my favorite dishes I've had here. The gnocchi was deep fried I think and placed on top of a cream sauce. It was fluffy and crispy all at the same time. If they happen to have something like this on the menu, you should get it.I've had 3 desserts total at Palomar - two of them were winners and one was just so-so. My favorite one was the Jerusalem Mess: labneh mousse, almond crumble, strawberries and sorrel. It was the perfect combo of tart and sweet. I normally like chocolate desserts over non-chocolate ones but this one hit it out of the park. I also got the Reverse Chocolate Fondue which had a crumble, banana financier, vanilla marshmallow and peanut tuile. It was also really good but I liked the Jerusalem Mess more. They usually have 4 desserts on the menu that change seasonally. To be honest, the desserts here are not the highlight of the meal, but the savory dishes are so good that I will overlook that.Overall, this is one of my favorite restaurants in London and favorites in the world -- so don't miss the chance to eat here if you can. Try to make a reservation ahead of time (either for the first seating at the bar, or for the restaurant section of the restaurant), or go early to put your name down and wait for a seat at the bar.

DpL0nL1AlYZz0Ap2Y_SEqg.text: One of the best restaurants in London - not to be missed - eggplant is a highlight - be sure to book in advance

eYhtAo2CmaVwRZZOsAw_Kw.text: Trendy, loud, and smelly boîte in Soho. It has a raw bar, a very lively counter space, offers cocktails (I had my shoshonna, quiet tasty), and an eclectic middle eastern inspired menu. Quiet popular, but we were able to get in the day of rez. The hostess took our name down upon arrival, then called us on our cell once a table was available. My sister refused to sit at the counter because of the intense allium and spice as well as fried food odors, so we retreated into the very cozy dining room. Our server, a delightful young woman, was attentive as a millennial can be. I forgive her few mistakes, such as forgetting to bring a dish or two, because she was so much fun. As for the food...Certainly, not the best food I've had in London. We tried quiet a few dishes, sharing them all. What I liked the best was also the least expensive item, the spicy experience, pickled small green chili with harissa. The tree of life, a head of broccoli charred and topped with pine nuts, served over a bed of yogurt, sounded promising, but was very very bland and undercooked. The chicken served on a cast iron hot plate suffered from the same. And the hummus? Well, I'm not one who will be rhapsodizing over the ubiquitous and overrated dip. I think there's too much hummus in the world. Burnt courgette tzatziki was too soupy, the truffle polenta serviceable. Would I go back there? Yes, if it were easy to get in after seeing a play and have a couple of mezes and a drink at the most. What it IS NOT IS THE MOST FABULOUS  FOOD in London, or elsewhere. Perhaps diners who think so, reach that conclusion not to look too foolish after waiting a a long while to be seated, and paying up a nice sum. Who knows?

photos.caption: Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Surly head chef, who didn't like my taking a picture of his bone marrow preparation.

jFZ8QKKFH3nahLw_zMpRng.text: Really great food, nice ambiance. Tables are quite close together and maneuvering in & out of seats/booths could be challenging for some. The serving sizes are tapas portions and we ordered about 8 items between 3 of us. The kubaneh, fattoush salad, and seared scallops were our favorites. The polenta was okay but nothing to write home about. Our least favorite was the fish tagine.

a1n4lfN10v2oyNcS3xqz3g.text: It was difficult to get a reservation and booked a couple weeks in advance for the kitchen counter.  We ordered the baba ganoush, shakshukit, the whole sea bass and polenta.  The sea bass was delicious and nicely cooked.  Baba ganoush has a nice roasted flavor.  Shakshukit was salty and oily.  It was too heavy for our tastes. While we enjoyed our meal, besides the sea bass the other dishes didn't stand out as items I would have to order if I went back.

KRe8v8KKOzRBv8cIa619kg.text: Put my name down for two at 6:30pm and was seated at 7:10pm (they estimated 8pm). I waited outside but they took my number down in case I wanted to walk around.One selection from each type of food was a great amount for two people. The kubaneh and tzatziki were amazing. I didn't expect "bread and yogurt dip" to be so memorable: The bread was like a giant cinnamon roll (as in fluffy and spiraled) and the tzatziki was unlike anything I've had before. Kind of tasted mustardy and had more character than other variations I've tried previously (which I enjoy but all blend together in my memory). My cousin and I were still eating it once the bread was gone. The beetroot carpaccio was underwhelming and we could have done without it. For the main course, we had the risotto special and polenta. Both were savory, rich, and delicious. Apps were definitely the star.The vibe of the restaurant was unique. It was cool sitting at the bar watching the kitchen and being served by the chefs. It was loud, but not hard to have a intelligible conversation. One weird thing was the dip/raw chef would taste the food and keep using the same spoon to mix the dish (and dishes after). Maybe it's just me, but I think he should have been using clean spoons.Overall really great experience. I'd recommend it, and I'd go back!

wwiJgeTaIlDl1mPPu-7uDQ.text: Wow, this place is amazing, small portions (taster size), food is amazing, the beetroot and baba ganoush are a must!!

JBE0eB73uJi4HwAfTNJpig.text: My friend chose the Palomar for one of her last meals in London before she went back to Australia (sob.) I did really like the food, but I wouldn't rush back.We'd heard that you could easily grab a table by the bar without booking, so I arrived early to put our name down. The lady at the front said someone had just cancelled, so they had a free table a bit later. This was all good, but she made me give my credit card details, and told me she'd charge £80 (£20 per head if we didn't show up.) That all seemed strange to me. She was basically telling me she'd just charged some poor soul £80 for not showing up, and that she'd have the same from us if we didn't show up too...even though this was only 1.5 hours notice. So...they seem really greedy - I basically decided I don't like the way they treat people before we even got to sit down!!Later when we made it into the restaurant I was happier. It has a nice relaxing atmosphere and our waiter was really friendly. Things I loved:- I probably shouldn't start with it, but the sorbet is amaaaazing. Seriously, this might be one of the nicest possible ways to finish a good meal.- I loooved the Tzatziki - it's just a dip, but their version was gorgeous. - I really liked the beetroot carpaccio.- The beets go prawns were nice too.Less impressive:- After telling us we'd under-ordered and we should get another item we were encouraged to try the truffle polenta...BUT in they didn't bother bringing it. In the end they brought it out after we'd finished everything else, but the flavours were just a bit too strong to eat it alone. Meh. I wasn't keen at all.- Octo-humus was also a bit of a disappointment. I love octopus when it is good, but this just wasn't fresh enough. Ah well. - We were really squished in!! We had 3 people on a table for four, but it was pretty cramped. - There was also a chilly draft, even right at the back of the restaurant.

Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Beetroot carpaccio
Photo of The Palomar Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. The beets go prawns

X8PWMf3_JuCEfCxFg7APjw.text: Amazing place for southern Spanish / North African food. We sat at the bar to watch the open kitchen fun. Food is delicious. Service is amazingly attentive. And just off Shaftesbury ave theatre district.
